dt: {bc}designed to incite to lust or depravity

dt.t: … the dance often becomes flagrantly {wi}obscene{/wi} and definitely provocative …

dt: {bc}containing or being language regarded as taboo in polite usage
{bc}repulsive by reason of crass disregard of moral or ethical principles

pt: {sc}coarse{/sc} {sc}vulgar{/sc} {sc}gross{/sc} {sc}obscene{/sc} {sc}ribald{/sc} mean offensive to good taste or morals. {sc}coarse{/sc} implies roughness, rudeness, or crudeness of spirit, behavior, or language.

pt.t: found the {it}coarse{/it} humor of coworkers offensive

pt: {sc}obscene{/sc} applies to anything strongly repulsive to the sense of decency and propriety especially in sexual matters.

pt.t: {it}obscene{/it} language not allowed on the air

pt: {sc}ribald{/sc} applies to what is amusingly or picturesquely vulgar or irreverent or mildly indecent.

pt.t: entertained the campers with {it}ribald{/it} folk songs

et: borrowed from Middle French & Latin; Middle French, "offensively indecent," borrowed from Latin {it}obscēnus, obscaenus{/it} "ill-omened, unpropitious, evoking disgust, loathsome, indecent, lewd," of uncertain origin

M. de Vaan ({it}Etymological Dictionary of Latin and the Other Italic Languages,{/it} Brill, 2008), following a suggestion by Ernout and Meillet, connects {it}obscaenus{/it} (if this was the earliest form) with scaevus "left, on the left-hand side, inauspicious," and proposes an original {it}*ob-skai-no-{/it} "coming from the left, unpropitious," from Indo-European {it}*skeh{inf}2{/inf}i-{/it} "in shadow."
shortdef: abhorrent to morality or virtue; specifically : designed to incite to lust or depravity
containing or being language regarded as taboo in polite usage
